awd_titl_txt: Broadening Participation of Latina/o Students in Engineering Using an Integrated Mathematics, Engineering and Computing Curriculum in Authentic, Out-of-School Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
The goals of the project are to motivate the participation of middle school students in urban and rural settings to pursue STEM and computing (STEM+C) careers. The project will develop an integrated curriculum that supports the learning of computing and engineering fundamentals through the underlying mathematics concepts. The after-school learning experiences focus on authentic work of computer engineers, student learning about computer programming, engineering design, and mathematics concepts.  The middle schools in the study have high enrollment of Latina/o students, a population which is under-represented in STEM majors in college and in STEM careers in the United States. Student learning and their attitudes toward and interests in STEM+C careers will make up the core focus of the research. The STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program seeks to advance multidisciplinary integration of computing in STEM teaching and learning through applied research and development across one or more domains; integration of STEM in computer science; and broadening participation in computer science. Investments are made in critical areas of pedagogy, pre-service and in-service teacher professional development. This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM). 

The project will address research questions that investigate student learning about engineering, mathematics and computer programming practices and concepts. The questions examine how the experience and resources can be designed to help students collaborate on programming tasks and learn about STEM+C related careers. The research design incorporates quantitative and qualitative data. The baseline data for students will document their knowledge, attitudes, and motivation related to computational thinking, mathematics and engineering. Subsequent data collection will document their work with a focus on their learning and engagement in computer engineering and mathematics. The study will also collect data from undergraduate student facilitators, middle school student co-facilitators, and teachers to understand how learning environments can be designed to support student learning of computer engineering integrated with mathematics with a particular focus on Latina/o learners. Overall, the project results should inform further curriculum design for integrating mathematics, computing, and engineering in middle school settings and supporting Latina/o students' learning in these domains.

AOLME Project Description

The Advancing Out-of-School Learning in Mathematics and Engineering (AOLME) Project developed, implemented, and revised integrated mathematics and computer programming curriculum using Python and the Raspberry Pi as the main platform in two bilingual middle schools located in a rural and an urban context. Level 1, taught in the spring, focused on the foundations of computer programming and image and video processing. Level 2, taught in the summer, covered object-oriented programming and robotics. The implementation took place in an after-school program with an undergraduate student serving as a facilitator and five small groups of four students each.

After middle school students experienced Level 1 of the curriculum, they were invited to participate as co-facilitators to teach the curriculum to other middle school students with an engineering undergraduate student. To take up this role, co-facilitators attended professional development sessions with teachers, graduate and undergraduate students focused on reviewing tasks in the curriculum, teacher talk moves, collaborative learning, and asset-based approaches to learning languages (Spanish and English). Over the course of the project, 111 primarily Latina/o middle school students, 4 teachers (2 from the rural and 2 from the urban school), 24 middle school co-facilitators, 32 undergraduate student facilitators, 15 graduate students, and over 111 parents participated in the project.

Intellectual Merit

Drawing from an interdisciplinary team with expertise in electrical and computer engineering and bilingual/mathematics education, AOLME principal investigators studied best practices to support students, in particular Latinx bilingual students, in learning an integrated mathematics and computer programming curriculum. A learning model that emerged from our observations and analysis of video data throughout the duration of the project was how students designed, modeled with mathematics, and implemented (DMI) their code to confirm what they had created from scratch. This framework highlights the importance of drawing from students’ interests and identities to share their stories through the creation of a final video project.

Broader Impacts

The AOLME project produced a framework for learning, an integrated mathematics and computer programming curriculum, a WebApp, and findings from several publications. These can inform mathematics and bilingual teachers, instructional coaches, curriculum designers, and mathematics and bilingual education researchers on how to support the learning of foundational concepts in computer programming while integrating mathematics with all students, including Latinx bilingual middle school students. A special issue that is in press through Teachers College Record, other publications and conference presentations:

  • Demonstrate how Latinx bilingual students can program when afforded opportunities to do so using design, model with mathematics, and implement as a learning model;
  • Provide examples of how teachers can implement the curriculum by including tasks in Spanish and English, video clips of student-facilitator interactions, video tutorials, and facilitator guidelines. This curriculum (still in progress) and the Image Generator Web App to create black/white, grayscale and color images are available online to provide access to students and educators globally. (See https://aolme.unm.edu/WebsiteModel/template/index.html and http://ivpcl.unm.edu/ivpclpages/Research/aolme/app/interactive-img-v2.html)
  • Share findings on 1) best teaching practice to support Latinx bilingual students in learning mathematics and computer programming, 2) the importance of translanguaging in supporting bilingual students to construct meaning of mathematics and computer programming with their peers, 3) students’ increase in mathematics attitude scales in enjoyment and self-confidence as they participated in the project and later became co-facilitators, and 4) the use of facilitators’ language and its impact on students’ positioning in learning mathematics and computer programming.
  • Position middle school co-facilitators as co-presenters at national conferences to share their trajectories from learners to leaders within the project through their work with teachers and other participants. Co-facilitators elaborated on our findings that described the quality of their experiences in the program, including facing the challenge, taking up the responsibility, relating to peers, affirming knowledge, and growing into leadership. The majority of the students who chose to be co-facilitators were bilingual and taught the curriculum bilingually to their peers. Co-facilitators reported having increased understanding of mathematics, computer programming, and improved skills in Spanish and English. Both AOLME and Non-AOLME students identified mathematics and computer programming as useful pre- and post-AOLME intervention. However, AOLME students', especially co-facilitators', enjoyment and self-confidence attitudes toward mathematics and computer programming were contrastingly higher than Non-AOLME students after participating in AOLME.
  • Demonstrate the need to continue broadening participation in STEM for Latinx students who often do not have access to these fields, especially those in rural communities and Title I schools where computer programming is often not offered. Currently, there are five middle school students who participated as students and as co-facilitators in AOLME and are now enrolled in a high school that supports them in entering STEM-related careers. All PIs continue to have contact with these students, and one of our doctoral students will conduct a longitudinal study about their experiences as co- facilitators and their future pathways.
